posts.title: Welcome to Ghost
posts.markdown:
You're in! Nice. We've put together a little post to introduce you to the Ghost editor and get you started. Go ahead and edit this post to get going and learn how it all works!

## Getting Started

Writing in markdown is really easy. In the left hand panel of Ghost, you simply write as you normally would. Where appropriate, you can use *formatting* shortcuts to style your content. For example, a list:

* Item number one
* Item number two
    * A nested item
* A final item

or with numbers!

1. Remember to buy some milk
2. Drink the milk
3. Tweet that I remembered to buy the milk, and drank it

### Links

Want to link to a source? No problem. If you paste in url, like http://ghost.org - it'll automatically be linked up. But if you want to customise your anchor text, you can do that too! Here's a link to [the Ghost website](http://ghost.org). Neat.

### What about Images?

Images work too! Already know the URL of the image you want to include in your article? Simply paste it in like this to make it show up:

![The Ghost Logo](http://tryghost.org/ghost.png)

Not sure which image you want to use yet? That's ok too. Leave yourself a descriptive placeholder and keep writing. Come back later and drag and drop the image in to upload:

![A bowl of bananas]


### Quoting

Sometimes a link isn't enough, you want to quote someone on what they've said. It was probably very wisdomous. Is wisdomous a word? Find out in a future release when we introduce spellcheck! For now - it's definitely a word.

> Wisdomous - it's definitely a word.

### Working with Code

Got a streak of geek? We've got you covered there, too. You can write inline `<code>` blocks really easily with back ticks. Want to show off something more comprehensive? 4 spaces of indentation gets you there.

    .awesome-thing {
        display: block;
        width: 100%;
    }

### Ready for a Break? 

Throw 3 or more dashes down on any new line and you've got yourself a fancy new divider. Aw yeah.

---

### Advanced Usage

There's one fantastic secret about Markdown. If you want, you can  write plain old HTML and it'll still work! Very flexible.

<input type="text" placeholder="I'm an input field!" />

That should be enough to get you started. Have fun - and let us know what you think :)
posts.html:
You're in! Nice. We've put together a little post to introduce you to the Ghost editor and get you started. Go ahead and edit this post to get going and learn how it all works!

Getting Started

Writing in markdown is really easy. In the left hand panel of Ghost, you simply write as you normally would. Where appropriate, you can use formatting shortcuts to style your content. For example, a list:

  • Item number one
  • Item number two
    • A nested item
  • A final item

or with numbers!

  1. Remember to buy some milk
  2. Drink the milk
  3. Tweet that I remembered to buy the milk, and drank it

Links

Want to link to a source? No problem. If you paste in url, like http://ghost.org - it'll automatically be linked up. But if you want to customise your anchor text, you can do that too! Here's a link to the Ghost website. Neat.

What about Images?

Images work too! Already know the URL of the image you want to include in your article? Simply paste it in like this to make it show up:

Not sure which image you want to use yet? That's ok too. Leave yourself a descriptive placeholder and keep writing. Come back later and drag and drop the image in to upload:

Quoting

Sometimes a link isn't enough, you want to quote someone on what they've said. It was probably very wisdomous. Is wisdomous a word? Find out in a future release when we introduce spellcheck! For now - it's definitely a word.

Wisdomous - it's definitely a word.

Working with Code

Got a streak of geek? We've got you covered there, too. You can write inline <code> blocks really easily with back ticks. Want to show off something more comprehensive? 4 spaces of indentation gets you there.

.awesome-thing {
    display: block;
    width: 100%;
}

Ready for a Break?

Throw 3 or more dashes down on any new line and you've got yourself a fancy new divider. Aw yeah.

Advanced Usage

There's one fantastic secret about Markdown. If you want, you can write plain old HTML and it'll still work! Very flexible.

That should be enough to get you started. Have fun - and let us know what you think :)

posts.title: ART+COPY+CODE
posts.markdown:
![](/content/images/2013/Oct/ARTCOPYCODE_720x220-1.png)

If you haven’t seen it, Google’s “Art, Copy & Code” creates a series of experiments and examples that re-imagine the idea/rules of advertising. It’s a lovely mix of storytelling and technology and will provide some great fodder when you’re looking for a fresh idea.
posts.html: If you haven’t seen it, Google’s “Art, Copy & Code” creates a series of experiments and examples that re-imagine the idea/rules of advertising. It’s a lovely mix of storytelling and technology and will provide some great fodder when you’re looking for a fresh idea.

posts.title: The Other Side of Data: Will It Help Us?
posts.markdown:
![](/content/images/2013/Oct/jonathan_harris_we_feel_fine_625x220.jpg)

Observation:

California-based digital artist [Jonathan Harris](http://www.number27.org/index.html) makes projects that reimagine how humans relate to technology and to each other. He combines elements of computer science, anthropology, visual art and storytelling.

His projects include building the world’s largest time capsule and documenting an Alaskan Eskimo whale hunt on the Arctic Ocean. He is also the co-creator of ‘[We Feel Fine](http://www.number27.org/index.html),’ a data set that continuously measures the emotional temperature of the human world through large-scale blog analysis.

Harris has created a new piece about data which he believes possesses the potential for both good and bad. The piece is written to illustrate various scenarios where data happens across our lives.

Harris posits a possible negative for every positive element about data, like “Data will help us remember, but will it let us forget? It will help politicians get elected, but will it help them lead?” The colored text that stands out against a black background as it gradually changes from red to yellow, green, blue, then purple.

You can see all the ways ‘Data Will Help Us’ below:

![](/content/images/2013/Oct/jonathan_harris_data_will_help_us_288x300.jpg)

Why this is interesting?

“Big data” can be powerful forecasting tools for businesses. Publishers and advertisers are tracking our data the kinds of websites we visit. Retail businesses are tracking data about our shopping habits, spending, and life stages. There are even apps and devices to track our sleeping patterns and eating habits.

Harris’ point of view on data is appropriate, and how data-tracking can impact our future in ways the average user is not fully aware. Let’s not have data get ahead of us. Let’s use data in ways that helps us make decisions for a better world, and not be led by fear.  Let’s use data to help free our minds of restraint and that there are ways to do more. Let’s use data in a way that enables creativity, freedom, and passion.

[Number27](http://www.number27.org/index.html)

Number27

posts.title: When you talk to the lamppost and it talks back: Smart cities get playful
posts.markdown:
![](/content/images/2013/Oct/1683301_inline_inline_2_talk_to_the_lamp_post_and_the_post_box_and_the_crane.jpg)

[Hello Lamp Post](http://www.hellolamppost.co.uk/)–is a project that will allow residents and visitors to the U.K. city “talk” to thousands of urban objects. “The end result has been described as a cross between a chat forum and an Artificial Intelligence conversation system with objects addressing individuals with questions that are location-specific with precise content, presentation, and tone crafted to stimulate conversation.”

The rationale on platform choice and level of detailed thinking for this initiative is amazing:”Though Hello Street Lamp could have been a smartphone app, the PAN team opted for SMS because it is more widely available, more intimate and, ultimately, more conversational.”

It is intriguing to think about how our interactions with not just mobile devices, people or brands can be enhanced; but really interactions with the world around us and everyday objects we pass by. How much does a lamppost witness in it’s ‘life’ that we could share if we could experience it or talk to it?

[Here’s the article](http://www.fastcocreate.com/1683301/when-you-talk-to-the-lamp-post-and-it-talks-back-smart-cities-get-playful).

The rationale on platform choice and level of detailed thinking for this initiative is amazing:”Though Hello Street Lamp could have been a smartphone app, the PAN team opted for SMS because it is more widely available, more intimate and, ultimately, more conversational.”

Here’s the article.

posts.title: Codecademy
posts.markdown:
![](/content/images/2013/Oct/code_academy_720x220.png)

These days anyone can be a developer. Want to build a website? Make an iPhone app? Take your basic skills to the next level with a little jQuery? Codecademy gives you the motivation and training essential to moving forward in a very self-taught industry. After a few courses (all free) you’ll be able to speak tech and seek out more advanced materials that will take your career to the next level.

[Start writing code today](http://www.codecademy.com/).
posts.html:
These days anyone can be a developer. Want to build a website? Make an iPhone app? Take your basic skills to the next level with a little jQuery? Codecademy gives you the motivation and training essential to moving forward in a very self-taught industry. After a few courses (all free) you’ll be able to speak tech and seek out more advanced materials that will take your career to the next level.

Start writing code today.

posts.title: Stealth Wear
posts.markdown:
![](/content/images/2013/Oct/stealth_wear_hero_600x220.jpg)

With the proliferation of camera tracking, geotagging, RFID, and self quantification over the last few years has come a new genre of wearables called Stealth Wear that the NY Times covered in a [recent article](http://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/30/technology/stealth-wear-aims-to-make-a-tech-statement.html).

Tapping into a highly contentious issue in the world via an interesting artistic commentary on the rapidly changing nature of personal privacy, I think this is an important precursor to take note of in a world where much of this anti-spyware wearable technology will probably be invisible to the naked eye in the near future.

![](/content/images/2013/Oct/cv_dazzle.jpg)

There’s a lot to be said about the fact that the aesthetics here are still predominately “futuristic” and loud, and especially that this article landed itself in the Style section. Between Google Glass, WikiLeaks, the Snowden scandal, and the ongoing online privacy discussion in our country and globally, this category currently seems to me another visible call to action, pointed at the mainstream, to make light of an important issue and attempt to move it forward. Will we be reshaping our relationship to our personal effects along with the policies that govern them?

Also check out the work of Todd Blatt, our very own 3D printing modeler extraordinaire, whose Google Glass accessory is covered in the article!

![](/content/images/2013/Oct/todd_glass.jpeg)
posts.html:
With the proliferation of camera tracking, geotagging, RFID, and self quantification over the last few years has come a new genre of wearables called Stealth Wear that the NY Times covered in a recent article.

Tapping into a highly contentious issue in the world via an interesting artistic commentary on the rapidly changing nature of personal privacy, I think this is an important precursor to take note of in a world where much of this anti-spyware wearable technology will probably be invisible to the naked eye in the near future.

There’s a lot to be said about the fact that the aesthetics here are still predominately “futuristic” and loud, and especially that this article landed itself in the Style section. Between Google Glass, WikiLeaks, the Snowden scandal, and the ongoing online privacy discussion in our country and globally, this category currently seems to me another visible call to action, pointed at the mainstream, to make light of an important issue and attempt to move it forward. Will we be reshaping our relationship to our personal effects along with the policies that govern them?

Also check out the work of Todd Blatt, our very own 3D printing modeler extraordinaire, whose Google Glass accessory is covered in the article!

posts.title: NUI: Natural Users Interface
posts.markdown:
![](/content/images/2013/Oct/720x220xScreen_Shot_2013_07_29_at_4_55_55_PM_720x220_png_pagespeed_ic_BQ8huIlr4o.png)

Read the Deck: [NUImeetupJack](http://imadeyouthis.com/innovatejack/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/NUImeetupJack.pdf)

This time we are thinking on the leading edge. This deck is about NUI: Natural User Interfaces.

Basically the ‘upcoming’ technology that uses natural human interactions and technology to communicate and accomplish tasks. think of Kinect, Leap Motion and Siri. etc.

A few highlights from the deck:

* Who, What, How, Why, UX
* Tons of awesome links and brand examples
* Jack example of incorporating NUI: Lego

posts.title: Mobile & Social Perspective
posts.markdown:
![](/content/images/2013/Oct/Screen_Shot_2013_07_30_at_9_51_01_AM1_300x225.png) Read the [Mobile Meetup Notes](http://imadeyouthis.com/innovatejack/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/MobileMeetupNotes.pdf) deck. **Engaging the Mobile Masses with Social**
With Jarrod Dicker of Time Inc., Jeff Stier of Ernst & Young, and Deepesh Banerji of [CBSSports.com](http://CBSSports.com) A few highlights from the deck: * Mobile platform optimization and design best practices * “Experiences should be created to translate across multiple platforms.” * Jack Tip: “Live events are the social ‘sweet spot’ for mobile device engagement”
posts.html:
Read the Mobile Meetup Notes deck.

Engaging the Mobile Masses with Social
With Jarrod Dicker of Time Inc., Jeff Stier of Ernst & Young, and Deepesh Banerji of CBSSports.com

A few highlights from the deck:

  • Mobile platform optimization and design best practices
  • “Experiences should be created to translate across multiple platforms.”
  • Jack Tip: “Live events are the social ‘sweet spot’ for mobile device engagement”

posts.title: Ghost Blogging Platform
posts.markdown:
![](/content/images/2013/Oct/Screen_Shot_2013_10_25_at_5_22_02_PM.png)

**A beautifully designed platform dedicated to one thing: Publishing.**

Ghost is an Open Source application which allows you to write and publish your own blog, giving you the tools to make it easy and even fun to do. It's simple, elegant, and designed so that you can spend less time making your blog work and more time blogging.

Jack's Innovation blog is running on Ghost. It's hip, it's new, and you can read more about it over at [ghost.org](http://ghost.org).
posts.html:

posts.title: Who Knew Subways Could Be Beautiful?
posts.markdown:
L'Oreal Intelligent Color Experience (created by RG/A Labs) allows for a personalized beauty vending machine located in the NYC Subway system.

If it all goes well, could be a WIN WIN WIN for Consumers, retailers and the MTA.

[Stand Clear of Closing Doors Protect Your Manicure](http://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/30/business/media/stand-clear-of-closing-doors-protect-your-manicure.html?ref=media&_r=3&)
posts.html:
L'Oreal Intelligent Color Experience (created by RG/A Labs) allows for a personalized beauty vending machine located in the NYC Subway system.

If it all goes well, could be a WIN WIN WIN for Consumers, retailers and the MTA.

Stand Clear of Closing Doors Protect Your Manicure

settings.value: A collection of innovative ideas, cool sh*t and smart thinking for Jack NY.
